content.value_statement: Working with time-series data can be challenging without proper guidance on hypertables, compression, and continuous aggregates. This skill provides comprehensive TimescaleDB documentation to help you build high-performance time-series applications with PostgreSQL.
actual_capabilities: Provides reference documentation for TimescaleDB hypertables creation and management
Explains compression strategies and policies for optimizing storage efficiency
Documents continuous aggregates for automated materialized view refresh
Covers hyperfunctions for advanced time-series data analysis
Details installation and configuration for self-hosted and cloud deployments
Includes time bucket functions for time-based grouping and aggregation
limitations: This is a reference documentation skill - it does not execute database queries
Does not provide live database connections or query execution
Does not install or configure TimescaleDB on your system
Requires existing TimescaleDB or Tiger Cloud service to apply the documentation

best_practices: Choose appropriate chunk_time_interval based on your memory constraints - indexes for active chunks should fit in 25% of RAM
Enable compression on hypertables that contain historical data to reduce storage costs by up to 90%
Use continuous aggregates for frequently queried aggregations to avoid scanning large datasets on each query
anti_patterns: Using a timestamp column without proper indexing for time-range queries
Creating hypertables without considering chunk size, leading to either too many small chunks or too few large chunks
Running analytical queries on uncompressed historical data without using continuous aggregates

faq.question: What PostgreSQL versions are supported by TimescaleDB?
faq.answer: TimescaleDB supports PostgreSQL versions 10 through 17, with specific version compatibility depending on the TimescaleDB release.

faq.question: What is the recommended chunk interval for hypertables?
faq.answer: Best practice is to set chunk intervals so that indexes for active chunks fit within 25% of available RAM, typically 1 day to 1 week.

faq.question: How does TimescaleDB differ from standard PostgreSQL for time-series?
faq.answer: TimescaleDB automatically partitions time-series data into chunks, enabling faster queries through chunk skipping and providing specialized time-series functions.

faq.question: Can I use TimescaleDB with existing PostgreSQL databases?
faq.answer: Yes, TimescaleDB is an extension that can be enabled on existing PostgreSQL databases without migrating to a new database system.

faq.question: What is the difference between continuous aggregates and regular materialized views?
faq.answer: Continuous aggregates are incrementally refreshed in the background, only processing new data, unlike materialized views which are fully recomputed on each refresh.

faq.question: How much storage space can compression save?
faq.answer: TimescaleDB compression typically reduces storage requirements by 80-90% for time-series data, depending on data patterns and column types.
